text: External Forced Convection and Natural Convection Significance of external flows and natural convection • Flows over objects are regarded as external flows, e.g. flow over a surface, flow over a sphere or cylinder. • Wide range of engineering applications for external flows in gas turbine blade cooling, heat exchangers, etc. • In the absence of an external means of forcing the fluid to flow, such as pumps and fans, the convection is termed natural or free convection. • There are many examples of free convection in natural and manmade systems. o The weather and its daily and seasonal changes are the result of natural heat convection between the surface of the earth and the atmosphere. o Any electronic device which does not have a fan relies on free convection for cooling. o Heating and air conditioning. Grashof number • Motion of fluid induced by natural convection forms a boundary layer over the solid surface. • This boundary layer is characterised by the so called Grashof number, which is defined as 𝐺𝑟𝑥 ≡ 𝑔𝛽(𝑇𝑠−𝑇∞)𝑥3 𝑣2 where 𝛽 is the volumetric thermal expansion coefficient and is a thermo-physical property of the fluid (for ideal gases 𝛽 = 1 𝑇). • Grashof number is a measure of relative strength of buoyancy and viscous forces.
